events.text:
Made by Viridino Studios (@ViridinoStudios)

Mateus Ferreira - Programmer
Twitter: @BonzerKitten
E-mail: ferreiramoreiramateus@gmail.com

Wesley Andrade - Artist
Twitter: @andrart7
E-mail: wesleymatos1989@gmail.com

Made with the support of patrons on https://www.patreon.com/viridinostudios
How far the player needs to move the analog stick before it starts to be recognized by the game.
The default screen refresh rate for testing.
How far or close the camera will be from the player.

children.text: Setup the level blocks by storing the initial position in local variables and creating a grid behind them.

actions.text: Create a grid behind the level block.

children.text: Setup the ground by adding it as a child of the nearest level block, so they always stay together.
Setup the flag by adding it as child of the nearest level block, so they always stay together.
Reset global variables to prevent traces from previous sessions.
Setup the player by adding its graphics to the collider as a child.
Receive and store input from the player to be used later in many situations.
Toggle input left.
Toggle input right.
Toggle input up.
Toggle input down.
Calculate both axis and looking angle based on the player input.
Move the player horizontally based on its horizontal axis.
Simulate player jump.
Only allow animation related stuff if the platform behavior is enabled, which means the player is currently controllable.
Mirror the player graphics based on its horizontal axis.
Change the animation states depending on what the player is currently doing.
Walk animation.
Idle animation.
Jump animation.
Fall animation.
Spawn different types of dust particles depending on the player actions.
Walking dust.
Landing dust.
Jumping dust.
Whether or not the level editor is enabled.
Which level block the cursor is over at the moment.
The first selected level block.
The second selected level block.
Whether or not the first level block is selected.
The lowest possible ID number in a scene.
The highest possible ID number in a scene.
How many level blocks can be fit in a row.
How long each animation takes in general.
Toggle the level editor on and off.
The level editor can only be enabled if cooldown timer is not running.
The level editor can only be enabled if the player is on floor.

actions.text: The acceleration in the player can make it keep playing the walk animation if the level editor is called in some very specific moments, so it's important to force the player to start the idle animation.

children.text: Disable the level editor by centering all level blocks and updating the cursor position.
Once the level blocks are centered, give control back to the player by releasing it from the level block an re-enabling the platform behavior.
Disable the level editor by spreading all level blocks, resetting all related parameters, updating the cursor position and disabling the player movement.

actions.text: Cancel the center level blocks timer, just to make the player wont be able to move if the level editor toggle is pressed multiple time in a short amount of time.

children.text: Spread the level blocks by increasing their position values in comparison with the layout center.
Update the cursor position.
Disable the player movement and attach it to the nearest level block, so they can be moved together.
Update the cursor position based on whether the level editor is enabled or not.
If the level editor is enabled, positionate the cursor on top of the currently selected level block.
If the level editor is disabled, positionate the cursor outside the layout, where it's not visible.
Change the cursor position based on the player input, but only if the level editor is enabled and the cooldown timer is not running.
Move the cursor left.
Move the cursor right.
Move the cursor up.
The cursor can only be moved up if there are enough level blocks above the currently selected one.
Move the cursor down.
The cursor can only be moved down if there are enough level blocks below the currently selected one.
Change the currently selected level block while also updating the cursor position.
Select a level block to be swapped.
Only allow a level block to be selected if the level editor is enabled and the cooldown timer is not running.
If the player has already selected the first level block, store its ID number and mark it with an earth symbol.
But only if the first level block selected is not identical to the second one.
The IID of the first level block.
The initial X position of the first level block.
The initial Y position of the first level block.
The ID number of the first level block.
The IID of the second level block.
The initial X position of the second level block.
The initial Y position of the second level block.
The ID number of the second level block.
Store all necessary temporary data for both first and second selected level blocks.
Move, update the initial position and set the next ID number of both first and second selected level blocks.
After the data has been stored and the level blocks moved, start a cooldown timer and mark the second selected level block with an earth symbol.
If the player haven't selected the first level block yet, store its ID number and mark it with an earth symbol.
When the first and second level blocks have been swapped, update the ID number and start the self destroy animation of their earth symbol.
Once the cooldown down timer is over, both selected level blocks will be done with their animations, so it's okay to disable the level editor.
Mark a level block by creating an earth symbol on top of it. It can be can considered some sort of visual feedback, so the player knows a level block has been selected.
Spawn a few fireflies that randomly fly around the lantern at the end of the level.
When a firefly stops moving, randomize the next angle and start to move again.
When the player collides with the lantern, spawn a few small explosions around the lantern with a increasingly delay.
Restart the game if the player goes outside the layout.
Restart the game.
Close the game.
